docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Thursday that its future health care obligation for retirees rose last year to $63.4 billion, from $57 billion in 2002. If not for the effects of the new Medicare legislation signed in December by President Bush, the obligation would have been $67.5 billion. The figures were disclosed in the company's annual report, which was released on Thursday. Many domestic manufacturers say that soaring health care costs have become their chief competitive burden.

headline.main: G.M. Says Costs For Retiree Care Top $60 Billion

docs.abstract: General Motors Corp says its future health care obligation for retirees rose last year to $63.4 billion, from $57 billion in 2002; obligation would have been $67.5 billion if not for effects of new Medicare legislation signed in December by Pres Bush; Ford Motor Co and Chrysler Group reinstate contributions to their employees' 401(k) plans; Ford also says it will begin paying bonuses of first time in three years to its top 6,200 managers worldwide (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, doctors hospitalized cancer patients before giving them chemotherapy, so worried were they about the retching, dehydration and weight loss that the drugs could cause. Now, most doctors treat cancer patients in their offices, allowing them to return home quickly or even go to work. But the federal Medicare program is changing the way it pays cancer doctors, and some oncologists are so angry that, hoping to turn patients into lobbyists, they are warning patients that they face a return to hospitalization and nausea.

headline.main: Among Cancer Doctors, a Medicare Revolt; New Payment System Spurs Talk of Return to Hospital Care and Old Drugs

docs.abstract: Medicare program is changing way it pays cancer doctors, and some oncologists are so angry that, hoping to turn patients into lobbyists, they are warning patients that they face return to hospitalization and nausea instead of current practice of treating patients in their offices; doctors in practice called Oncology Associates in Hartford wrote letter recently to their patients saying that because of new reimbursement system, patients might have to 'switch to older medications'; contended that they would be financially unable to give chemotherapy medications which cost more than Medicare reimbursement; similar letters are being delivered to patients around country, according to oncologists, advocates for cancer patients and American Society of Clinical Oncology, nation's largest professional society of cancer doctors; Dr Peter D Eisenberg of Greenbrae, Calif, says his practice has cut staff and can no longer provide all services patients have grown accustomed to; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Years ago, doctors hospitalized cancer patients before giving them chemotherapy, so worried were they about the retching, dehydration and weight loss that the drugs could cause. Now, most doctors treat cancer patients in their offices, allowing them...

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said on Wednesday that advertisements and brochures prepared by the Bush administration to publicize a new Medicare law, although not illegal, misrepresented the prescription drug benefits that would be offered to millions of elderly and disabled people. The fliers and advertisements do not violate restrictions on the use of federal money for ''publicity or propaganda purposes,'' but they are flawed by ''omissions and other weaknesses,'' said the legal opinion by Anthony H. Gamboa, general counsel of the accounting office.

headline.main: A Watchdog Sees Flaws In Bush's Ads On Medicare

docs.abstract: General Accounting Office says ads and brochures prepared by Bush administration to publicize new Medicare law misrepresent prescription drug benefits, even if they do not constitute illegal campaign material as Democrats charge (S)
docs.snippet: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said on Wednesday that advertisements and brochures prepared by the Bush administration to publicize a new Medicare law, although not illegal, misrepresented the prescription drug...

docs.lead_paragraph: Housing officials told members of the City Council yesterday that they needed an additional $15 million and 300 new employees to comply with a new lead-paint law that is to go into effect in August. During a budget hearing before the Council's Committee on Housing and Buildings, the officials also suggested that the city needed more time to train employees and contractors. They also expressed concern that some contracting work could be delayed because companies would not have enough time to go through the federal Environmental Protection Agency's certification process.

headline.main: Lead-Paint Law Requires Millions More, Officials Say

docs.abstract: New York City housing officials tell City Council committee that they need additional $15 million and 300 new employees to comply with new lead-paint law that goes into effect in August; say that city could also need more time to train employees and contractors and that work may be delayed because companies will not have enough time to go through federal certification process (M)

headline.main: A Waiter's Job: At Least It's Staying Here

docs.abstract: Stephen Burns letter holds raising minimum wage to a real 'living wage,' creating national health-care system and reforming labor laws to strengthen unions would go a long way to improve lives of millions of working people, even as some jobs move overseas

docs.lead_paragraph: Tuition at New York City's elite private schools is at or near $26,000 for the coming school year, with average increases as high as 9 percent and a growing number of schools charging the same price for kindergarten as for high school. Private school families received their contracts -- a euphemism for bills -- in recent weeks and word spread quickly about those with the biggest increases.

headline.main: Tuition Hits $26,000, and in Private School New York, That's Just for Kindergarten

docs.abstract: Tuition at private schools in New York City tops $28,000, with some increases almost reaching 9 percent; parents of kindergarten students see sharpest increases, as schools start charging them as much as other grades; schools say that teachers' salaries and health plans account for most of increases; education experts say that there is not decline in demand, no matter what schools charge, at least in city; raises cause many parents to sacrifice; graph (M)

byline.original: By JANE GROSS; Lia Miller contributed reporting for this article

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: A cholesterol-lowering study whose results were announced this week has a wealth of important implications. The findings could certainly presage a significant change in the way heart disease patients are treated. It should also start a careful evaluation of whether normally healthy people could benefit from a sharp drug-induced reduction in their cholesterol levels. There may also be major side effects for the economy: the potential health benefits could drive up the use of high-cost drugs in a nation that is already struggling to pay its medical bills. Finally, the study should send a message to Congress and federal regulators about the value of comparative testing of prescription drugs. The study, sponsored by Bristol-Myers Squibb and led by researchers at Harvard University's medical complex, provided persuasive evidence that lowering cholesterol far beyond currently recommended levels was beneficial in patients who had already suffered a heart attack or unstable angina.
docs.abstract: Editorial on important findings of cholesterol-lowering study holds that new drug treatments may improve care of heart patents but may also increase drugs costs

docs.lead_paragraph: There is free lunch virtually every day for Medicare enrollees in the cafeterias and roadside restaurants here in Hernando County, a semirural expanse of scrub pine, golfers' subdivisions and medical strip malls 50 miles north of Tampa. No fewer than five H.M.O. companies are scrambling to sign up elderly members in the county, and the pitches being delivered over lunch tables here herald a national surge in Medicare managed care prompted by the Bush administration's plan to pump $46 billion into these programs over the next 10 years.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Return For a Piece Of Medicare Pie

docs.abstract: Managed care companies that pulled out of areas across country few years ago are returning now that federal Medicare reimbursement rates have gone up; Bush administration's plan caled for $46 billion to be pumped into these health insurance programs over next 10 years; number of Medicare beneficiaries enrolling in managed care plans has started to rise in Hernando County, Fla; Humana Inc's chief executive Michael McCallister comments; map; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the nation's labor leaders gathered at a luxury seaside hotel here, they were struggling on Monday to find ways to keep the union movement from sinking further after it suffered several recent setbacks. In the biggest confrontation in years, a 138-day dispute involving 59,000 California supermarket workers, the companies trounced the union, obtaining a two-tier contract that means lower wages and fewer health benefits for new employees.

headline.main: Labor Is Feeling Embattled As Union Leaders Convene

docs.abstract: Labor leaders gathering for AFL-CIO executive council meeting, Bal Harbour, Fla, seek ways to keep union movement from sinking further in wake of several recent setbacks; AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney comments on combatting shrinking union membership, interview; some union presidents say situation is so dire that AFL-CIO should focus on just two activities, politics and organizing; some even cite need for more aggressive, growth-minded group because AFL-CIO often seems paralyzed by its consensus requirements; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's nominee to run Medicare and Medicaid, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, said Monday that he would work with Congress on bipartisan legislation to assure the safety of prescription drugs imported from Canada. The way to do that is by giving the Food and Drug Administration more money, more personnel and more power to police imports, Dr. McClellan said at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Finance Committee.
docs.abstract: Dr Mark B McClellan, Pres Bush's nominee to run Medicare and Medicaid, softens his stance on drugs imported from Canada, Senate confirmation hearing; says he would work with Congress on bipartisan legislation to assure safety of such drugs, suggesting broadening powers of Food and Drug Administration; photo (M)
